items.standfirst: IOC bans Vladyslav Heraskevych for repeatedly wearing helmet that depicts Ukrainian athletes killed in war with Russia.
items.content: IOC bans Vladyslav Heraskevych for repeatedly wearing helmet that depicts Ukrainian athletes killed in war with Russia.

items.title: Ukrainian Olympian banned from competing over helmet honouring war dead

items.content: A Ukrainian skeleton racer has been banned from competing at the Winter Olympics after he insisted on wearing a helmet depicting athletes killed since Russia's invasion.

items.title: Ukraine skeleton racer disqualified from Olympics over memorial helmet
items.standfirst: Ukrainian skeleton racer Vladyslav Heraskevych was disqualified from the Winter Olympics by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) on Thursday for his insistance on wearing a helmet depicting Ukrainian sportsmen and women killed during the war with Russia. The IOC said that the athlete had not adhered to its "athlete expression guidelines".
items.content: Ukrainian skeleton racer Vladyslav Heraskevych was disqualified from the Winter Olympics by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) on Thursday for his insistance on wearing a helmet depicting Ukrainian sportsmen and women killed during the war with Russia. The IOC said that the athlete had not adhered to its "athlete expression guidelines".

items.title: House Republicans rebel against Canada tariffs

The first-time move is mostly symbolic: Lawmakers would need two-thirds of the chamber to overrule Trump’s…
items.content: President Donald Trump’s trade agenda is more politically vulnerable after six House Republicans voted with Democrats on Wednesday to scrap his administration’s tariffs on Canada. The first-time move is mostly symbolic: Lawmakers would need two-thirds of the chamber to overrule Trump’s…

items.title: Tariff votes hand Republicans an unwanted referendum on affordability
items.standfirst: A small GOP rebellion is unleashing a flood of House votes on President Donald Trump’s tariff policies in the coming weeks — handing Democrats a powerful tool to hammer Republicans on affordability issues ahead of the November midterms. House leaders had shielded their most vulnerable Republicans…
items.content: A small GOP rebellion is unleashing a flood of House votes on President Donald Trump’s tariff policies in the coming weeks — handing Democrats a powerful tool to hammer Republicans on affordability issues ahead of the November midterms. House leaders had shielded their most vulnerable Republicans…

items.title: US House overturns Trump’s Canada tariffs in rare bipartisan rebuke
items.standfirst: The US House voted 219-211 on Wednesday to challenge President Donald Trump’s tariffs on Canada, with several Republicans joining Democrats in a rare rebuke of his trade policy. The largely symbolic measure seeks to end the national emergency underpinning the tariffs and now heads to the Senate.
items.content: The US House voted 219-211 on Wednesday to challenge President Donald Trump’s tariffs on Canada, with several Republicans joining Democrats in a rare rebuke of his trade policy. The largely symbolic measure seeks to end the national emergency underpinning the tariffs and now heads to the Senate.

items.title: US House votes to overturn Trump's tariffs on Canada
items.standfirst: Six Republican lawmakers joined Democrats to back a resolution that seeks to end the tariffs Trump imposed on Canada last year.
items.content: Six Republican lawmakers joined Democrats to back a resolution that seeks to end the tariffs Trump imposed on Canada last year.

items.title: US House backs bid to block Canada tariffs in rebuke of Trump
items.standfirst: Republicans join Democrats in objecting to national emergency US president declared to impose tariffsThe US House on Wednesday voted to rescind tariffs that Donald Trump imposed on Canada last year, a rare bipartisan rebuke of the White House’s trade policy as the president threatened electoral retaliation against any Republican who defied him.The largely symbolic resolution to disapprove of the national emergency Trump declared to impose tariffs on Canada passed 219 to 211, with six Republicans – Don Bacon of Nebraska, Thomas Massie of Kentucky, Brian Fitzpatrick of Pennsylvania, Kevin Kiley of California, Dan Newhouse of Washington and Jeff Hurd of Colorado – voting with all Democrats except Jared Golden of Maine, who voted against it. Continue reading...
items.content: Republicans join Democrats in objecting to national emergency US president declared to impose tariffsThe US House on Wednesday voted to rescind tariffs that Donald Trump imposed on Canada last year, a rare bipartisan rebuke of the White House’s trade policy as the president threatened electoral retaliation against any Republican who defied him.The largely symbolic resolution to disapprove of the national emergency Trump declared to impose tariffs on Canada passed 219 to 211, with six Republicans – Don Bacon of Nebraska, Thomas Massie of Kentucky, Brian Fitzpatrick of Pennsylvania, Kevin Kiley of California, Dan Newhouse of Washington and Jeff Hurd of Colorado – voting with all Democrats except Jared Golden of Maine, who voted against it. Continue reading...

items.title: House votes to rescind Trump's Canada tariffs
items.standfirst: The measure's passage is largely symbolic as it's likely to be vetoed by the president if it survives a Senate vote.
items.content: The measure's passage is largely symbolic as it's likely to be vetoed by the president if it survives a Senate vote.

clusters.title: Canada mourns 9 pupils killed in school shooting
clusters.neutral_headline: Canada police identify shooting suspect as 18-year-old Jesse Van Rootselaar
bullet_summary: Canada is in mourning after a school shooting in British Columbia that killed nine people; the 18-year-old suspect was later found dead from a self-inflicted wound
Authorities said the suspect had previously been the subject of police welfare checks
The suspect’s mother and step-brother were later found dead at the family home, police said
The body of the shooter, Jesse Van Rootselaar, was also found with a self-inflicted gunshot wound

items.title: Canada mourns 9 pupils killed in school shooting
items.standfirst: Canada is in mourning after a school shooting in British Columbia that killed nine people; the 18-year-old suspect was later found dead from a self-inflicted wound. Authorities said the suspect had previously been the subject of police welfare checks. Prime Minister Mark Carney ordered federal flags to fly at half-mast for seven days in tribute to the victims.
items.content: Canada is in mourning after a school shooting in British Columbia that killed nine people; the 18-year-old suspect was later found dead from a self-inflicted wound. Authorities said the suspect had previously been the subject of police welfare checks. Prime Minister Mark Carney ordered federal flags to fly at half-mast for seven days in tribute to the victims.

items.title: Canada police identify shooting suspect as 18-year-old Jesse Van Rootselaar
items.standfirst: Police say the suspect had apprehended for a mental health assessment on more than one occasion.
items.content: Police say the suspect had apprehended for a mental health assessment on more than one occasion.

items.title: Police identify 18-year-old as suspect in Tumbler Ridge shooting
items.standfirst: A candlelit vigil was held on Wednesday night in the remote British Columbia town where six people were killed and dozens injured.
items.content: A candlelit vigil was held on Wednesday night in the remote British Columbia town where six people were killed and dozens injured.

items.title: Tumbler Ridge mass shooting: What we know so far
items.standfirst: Eight people have been killed and 25 injured in the shootings at a school and home in a rural community in western Canada, police say.
items.content: Eight people have been killed and 25 injured in the shootings at a school and home in a rural community in western Canada, police say.

items.title: Canadian police identify suspect in school massacre that left nine dead
items.standfirst: A teacher and five students among those killed in attack in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia, on TuesdayCanadian police have identified the suspect who carried out a school massacre in remote British Columbia as an 18-year old with a history of mental health problems.Six people, including a teacher and five students, were killed in the attack on Tuesday in the town of Tumbler Ridge, in the foothills of the Rocky mountains. The suspect’s mother and step-brother were later found dead at the family home, police said. The body of the shooter, Jesse Van Rootselaar, was also found with a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Continue reading...
items.content: A teacher and five students among those killed in attack in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia, on TuesdayCanadian police have identified the suspect who carried out a school massacre in remote British Columbia as an 18-year old with a history of mental health problems.Six people, including a teacher and five students, were killed in the attack on Tuesday in the town of Tumbler Ridge, in the foothills of the Rocky mountains. The suspect’s mother and step-brother were later found dead at the family home, police said. The body of the shooter, Jesse Van Rootselaar, was also found with a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Continue reading...

items.title: Canada shooting: Nine dead including suspect in attack on Tumbler Ridge high school, police say
items.standfirst: More than 25 people injured, including two with life-threatening injuries, after shooting at secondary school and local residenceTumbler Ridge school shooting: latest updatesWhat we know so far about the Tumbler Ridge shootingNine people have been killed and dozens injured after an assailant opened fire at a school in western Canada, in one of the deadliest mass shootings in the country’s history. The suspect was later found dead from what appeared to be a self-inflicted injury.Police found six people dead inside the high school in the remote town of Tumbler Ridge in British Columbia, with a further two bodies found at a residence believed to be connected to the incident. Continue reading...
items.content: More than 25 people injured, including two with life-threatening injuries, after shooting at secondary school and local residenceTumbler Ridge school shooting: latest updatesWhat we know so far about the Tumbler Ridge shootingNine people have been killed and dozens injured after an assailant opened fire at a school in western Canada, in one of the deadliest mass shootings in the country’s history. The suspect was later found dead from what appeared to be a self-inflicted injury.Police found six people dead inside the high school in the remote town of Tumbler Ridge in British Columbia, with a further two bodies found at a residence believed to be connected to the incident. Continue reading...

items.content: Members of the remote community have spoken of their fear and uncertainty after nine people were killed.

items.title: Nine people killed in a mass shooting involving a school in British Columbia
items.standfirst: Seven people were fatally shot at a school in British Columbia, while two others were found dead at a residence believed to be connected to the campus shooting. The suspected shooter was also found dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound. The motive surrounding the shooting is still being investigated.
items.content: Seven people were fatally shot at a school in British Columbia, while two others were found dead at a residence believed to be connected to the campus shooting. The suspected shooter was also found dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound. The motive surrounding the shooting is still being investigated.

items.content: Eight people have been killed in one of Canada's deadliest mass shootings, which also left the attacker dead.

items.title: 10 people dead, including suspect, in British Columbia mass shooting
items.standfirst: Police in Canada say a gunman killed seven people at a school in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia, secondary school, while two others were found dead at a residence believed to be connected to the campus shooting. The suspected shooter was also found dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, the agency said.
items.content: Police in Canada say a gunman killed seven people at a school in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia, secondary school, while two others were found dead at a residence believed to be connected to the campus shooting. The suspected shooter was also found dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, the agency said.

items.title: Shooter in mass killing in Canada was a troubled teenager, police say

items.content: The person accused of fatally shooting eight people and injuring two dozen more in the tiny Canadian town of Tumbler Ridge was identified by police Wednesday as Jesse Van Rootselaar, 18

clusters.title: Polls close in first election since Gen Z protests ousted Bangladesh leader
clusters.neutral_headline: Polls close in first election since Gen Z protests ousted Bangladesh leader
bullet_summary: Except for a single reported incident, voting in Bangladesh appears to be proceeding peacefully, FRANCE 24’s correspondent reports
Reported by BBC World, France24, Al Jazeera and others

items.title: Polls close in first election since Gen Z protests ousted Bangladesh leader
items.standfirst: Voters are hoping for a return to democracy after 15 years of authoritarian rule under Sheikh Hasina.
items.content: Voters are hoping for a return to democracy after 15 years of authoritarian rule under Sheikh Hasina.

items.title: Landmark Bangladeshi election takes place under heavy security
items.standfirst: Except for a single reported incident, voting in Bangladesh appears to be proceeding peacefully, FRANCE 24’s correspondent reports.This election is seen as a crucial test for Bangladesh’s democracy after years of political unrest. Voting is taking place under tight security and will determine the country’s leadership following the collapse of Sheikh Hasina’s government in 2024.
items.content: Except for a single reported incident, voting in Bangladesh appears to be proceeding peacefully, FRANCE 24’s correspondent reports.This election is seen as a crucial test for Bangladesh’s democracy after years of political unrest. Voting is taking place under tight security and will determine the country’s leadership following the collapse of Sheikh Hasina’s government in 2024.

items.title: Historic parliamentary vote underway in Bangladesh
items.standfirst: Bangladesh is holding its first parliamentary elections since the ousting of former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in 2024, with voters electing 300 lawmakers directly and 50 women from party lists. The main contenders are the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) and the Islamist-led Jamaat coalition, as Hasina’s Awami Party has been barred from participating.
items.content: Bangladesh is holding its first parliamentary elections since the ousting of former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in 2024, with voters electing 300 lawmakers directly and 50 women from party lists. The main contenders are the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) and the Islamist-led Jamaat coalition, as Hasina’s Awami Party has been barred from participating.

items.title: Bangladesh election live results 2026: By the numbers
items.standfirst: Nearly 127 million eligible voters are electing the next prime minister and parliament for a five-year term.
items.content: Nearly 127 million eligible voters are electing the next prime minister and parliament for a five-year term.

items.title: Bangladesh votes in its first election since the 2024 Gen Z uprising that ousted Hasina
items.standfirst: Voters across Bangladesh are casting ballots in a parliamentary election seen as a key test for the country’s democracy after years of political unrest. More than 127 million people are eligible to vote in the first election since former prime minister Sheikh Hasina’s government collapsed in 2024 following mass protests often described as a Gen Z-led uprising. Results are expected on Friday, as FRANCE 24's Navodita Kumari explains.
items.content: Voters across Bangladesh are casting ballots in a parliamentary election seen as a key test for the country’s democracy after years of political unrest. More than 127 million people are eligible to vote in the first election since former prime minister Sheikh Hasina’s government collapsed in 2024 following mass protests often described as a Gen Z-led uprising. Results are expected on Friday, as FRANCE 24's Navodita Kumari explains.

items.title: Bangladesh votes in first general election since bloody ousting of Sheikh Hasina

items.title: Bangladesh votes in landmark polls after deadly 2024 uprising
items.standfirst: Bangladeshis voted on Thursday in the first election since a deadly 2024 uprising, with parties sidelined under Sheikh Hasina returning to contest power against a formidable political heir leading an Islamist-backed coalition. Long queues formed at polling stations in the capital Dhaka as voting began nationwide.
items.content: Bangladeshis voted on Thursday in the first election since a deadly 2024 uprising, with parties sidelined under Sheikh Hasina returning to contest power against a formidable political heir leading an Islamist-backed coalition. clusters.title: US Pam Bondi faces backlash over release of Epstein documents

bullet_summary: Reported by France24, CBS News, Financial Times

items.title: US Pam Bondi faces backlash over release of Epstein documents
items.standfirst: US Attorney General Pam Bondi faced intense questioning over the handling of Jeffrey Epstein files after documents released victims’ personal information while redacting many alleged abusers’ names. Bondi denied wrongdoing but faced criticism from both Democrats and some Republicans.
items.content: US Attorney General Pam Bondi faced intense questioning over the handling of Jeffrey Epstein files after documents released victims’ personal information while redacting many alleged abusers’ names. Bondi denied wrongdoing but faced criticism from both Democrats and some Republicans.

items.title: US Attorney General Bondi deflects questions, clashes with democrats over Epstein files
items.standfirst: US Attorney General Pam Bondi on Wednesday forcefully defended her department's handling of the files related to convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, an issue that has dogged her tenure. With victims of Epstein seated behind her, Bondi tried to deflect from relentless criticism by mocking her Democratic questioners and praising Trump over the performance of the stock market.
items.content: US Attorney General Pam Bondi on Wednesday forcefully defended her department's handling of the files related to convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, an issue that has dogged her tenure. With victims of Epstein seated behind her, Bondi tried to deflect from relentless criticism by mocking her Democratic questioners and praising Trump over the performance of the stock market.

clusters.title: 'Dawson's Creek' star James Van Der Beek dies at 48
clusters.neutral_headline: James Van Der Beek, "Dawson's Creek" star, dies at 48
bullet_summary: Van Der Beek, who was married and had six children, announced his cancer diagnosis in 2024
Reported by France24, CBS News

items.title: 'Dawson's Creek' star James Van Der Beek dies at 48
items.standfirst: US actor James Van Der Beek, the star of the American TV series "Dawson's Creek," died on Wednesday at age 48 after a battle with colorectal cancer. "Our beloved James David Van Der Beek passed peacefully this morning. He met his final days with courage, faith, and grace," read a post on his Instagram page. Van Der Beek, who was married and had six children, announced his cancer diagnosis in 2024.
items.content: US actor James Van Der Beek, the star of the American TV series "Dawson's Creek," died on Wednesday at age 48 after a battle with colorectal cancer. "Our beloved James David Van Der Beek passed peacefully this morning. He met his final days with courage, faith, and grace," read a post on his Instagram page. Van Der Beek, who was married and had six children, announced his cancer diagnosis in 2024.

items.title: Britney Spears Sells Music Catalogue For $200 Million
items.standfirst: Pop superstar Britney Spears sold the rights to her entire music catalogue to independent music publisher Primary Wave for around $200m in late December 2025, according to showbiz website TMZ. Details of the sale and the exact price of Spears’ catalogue have not been made public, and neither…

items.title: Britney Spears sells music catalog for some $200 million
items.standfirst: US singer #BritneySpears has become the latest musician to sell the rights to her catalog that includes hits like "...Baby One More Time" and "Oops!...I Did It Again," US media reported Tuesday. The deal is believed to be worth around $200 million.
items.content: US singer #BritneySpears has become the latest musician to sell the rights to her catalog that includes hits like "...Baby One More Time" and "Oops!...I Did It Again," US media reported Tuesday. The deal is believed to be worth around $200 million.

items.title: Jim Ratcliffe accused of hypocrisy after saying UK ‘colonised’ by immigrants
items.standfirst: Manchester United co-owner, who lives in Monaco, faces growing backlash for using ‘far-right narratives’UK politics live – latest updatesThe Monaco-based billionaire Jim Ratcliffe has been accused of hypocrisy and using “far-right narratives”, as a backlash grew over his claims that the UK was being “colonised” by immigrants.Fans called the Manchester United co-owner’s comments “disgraceful and deeply divisive”, while Keir Starmer said his claim was “offensive and wrong”, and called on the Ineos chief executive to “apologise immediately”. Continue reading...

items.title: UK's Schroders pops 28% on Nuveen takeover that's set to create asset management giant
items.standfirst: Schroders soared to the top of the Stoxx 600 on Thursday, hitting a 52-week high, after U.S. fund management giant Nuveen said it would buy the U.K.'s largest standalone asset management. items.title: Schroders agrees £9.9bn takeover by US investor, ending 200 years of family ownership
items.standfirst: British asset management group’s deal with Nuveen will create one of world’s biggest fund managersSchroders has agreed a £9.9bn takeover by a US investor, ending two centuries of family ownership of the historic British asset management group.Chicago-based Nuveen will buy the City firm, it said on Thursday, in a deal that will create one of the world’s biggest fund managers, controlling about $2.5tn (£1.8tn) of assets. Continue reading...
items.content: British asset management group’s deal with Nuveen will create one of world’s biggest fund managersSchroders has agreed a £9.9bn takeover by a US investor, ending two centuries of family ownership of the historic British asset management group.Chicago-based Nuveen will buy the City firm, it said on Thursday, in a deal that will create one of the world’s biggest fund managers, controlling about $2.5tn (£1.8tn) of assets. clusters.title: House GOP pushes strict proof-of-citizenship requirement for voters
clusters.neutral_headline: House GOP pushes strict proof-of-citizenship requirement for voters
bullet_summary: Reported by NPR News, CBS News

items.title: House GOP pushes strict proof-of-citizenship requirement for voters
items.standfirst: House Republicans rushed to approve legislation on Wednesday that would impose new proof-of-citizenship requirements ahead of the midterm elections, a Trump administration priority that faces blowback in the Senate.
items.content: House Republicans rushed to approve legislation on Wednesday that would impose new proof-of-citizenship requirements ahead of the midterm elections, a Trump administration priority that faces blowback in the Senate.(Image credit: Kathy Kmonicek)

items.title: House approves the SAVE America Act as GOP makes election bill push
items.standfirst: The SAVE America Act would implement strict new requirements for registering to vote and casting ballots.
items.content: The SAVE America Act would implement strict new requirements for registering to vote and casting ballots.

clusters.title: 2026 Olympics: Golden day for France's Simon and ice dancing duo Cizeron, Fournier Beaudry
clusters.neutral_headline: Madison Chock and Evan Bates claim silver in ice dance at 2026 Winter Olympics
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, CBS News

items.title: 2026 Olympics: Golden day for France's Simon and ice dancing duo Cizeron, Fournier Beaudry
items.standfirst: It was a banner day for Team France on February 11, 2026 at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics. In the women's 15km individual biathlon, Julia Simon claimed gold ahead of teammate Lou Jeanmonnot, who took silver. In moguls, Perrine Laffont grabbed bronze, eight years after her Pyeongchang triumph. The highlight came on the ice, where Laurence Fournier Beaudry and Guillaume Cizeron won Olympic gold in figure skating.
items.content: It was a banner day for Team France on February 11, 2026 at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics. In the women's 15km individual biathlon, Julia Simon claimed gold ahead of teammate Lou Jeanmonnot, who took silver. In moguls, Perrine Laffont grabbed bronze, eight years after her Pyeongchang triumph. The highlight came on the ice, where Laurence Fournier Beaudry and Guillaume Cizeron won Olympic gold in figure skating.

items.title: Madison Chock and Evan Bates claim silver in ice dance at 2026 Winter Olympics
items.standfirst: Madison Chock and Evan Bates claimed a silver medal at the 2026 Winter Olympics on Wednesday following a stunning free dance routine.
items.content: Madison Chock and Evan Bates claimed a silver medal at the 2026 Winter Olympics on Wednesday following a stunning free dance routine.

items.title: France’s Cizeron, Fournier Beaudry win ice dance gold at 2026 Olympics
items.standfirst: French figure skaters Guillaume Cizeron and Laurence Fournier Beaudry won Olympic gold in ice dance on Wednesday, capping a remarkable rise after pairing up just one year ago. The duo topped reigning world champions Madison Chock and Evan Bates of the United States following the free dance final.
items.content: French figure skaters Guillaume Cizeron and Laurence Fournier Beaudry won Olympic gold in ice dance on Wednesday, capping a remarkable rise after pairing up just one year ago. The duo topped reigning world champions Madison Chock and Evan Bates of the United States following the free dance final.

clusters.title: Salesforce workers outraged after CEO makes joke about ICE watching them
clusters.neutral_headline: Salesforce workers outraged after CEO makes joke about ICE watching them
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, Wired

items.title: Salesforce workers outraged after CEO makes joke about ICE watching them
items.standfirst: Marc Benioff’s remarks criticized as employees were reportedly planning to urge him to cancel business with agencyMarc Benioff, the Salesforce CEO and co-founder, is facing growing criticism over a joke he made about US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) monitoring international employees during an event for the company.Employees publicly expressed outrage about Benioff’s comments in his keynote address at an internal conference in Las Vegas on Tuesday, and leaders at Slack, which Salesforce owns, have said he should apologize. Continue reading...
items.content: Marc Benioff’s remarks criticized as employees were reportedly planning to urge him to cancel business with agencyMarc Benioff, the Salesforce CEO and co-founder, is facing growing criticism over a joke he made about US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) monitoring international employees during an event for the company.Employees publicly expressed outrage about Benioff’s comments in his keynote address at an internal conference in Las Vegas on Tuesday, and leaders at Slack, which Salesforce owns, have said he should apologize. Continue reading...

items.title: Salesforce Workers Circulate Open Letter Urging CEO Marc Benioff to Denounce ICE
items.standfirst: The letter comes after Benioff joked at a company event on Monday that ICE was monitoring international employees in attendance, sparking immediate backlash.
items.content: The letter comes after Benioff joked at a company event on Monday that ICE was monitoring international employees in attendance, sparking immediate backlash.

items.title: Police release call from boy, 13, who swam for hours to save his family stranded at sea
items.standfirst: Authorities have released the audio of an emergency call made by a 13-year-old boy who swam for hours to save his family after they were swept out to sea.
items.content: Authorities have released the audio of an emergency call made by a 13-year-old boy who swam for hours to save his family after they were swept out to sea.

items.title: Emergency call released of boy who swam for hours to save family
items.standfirst: Austin Appelbee, 13, swam to get help for his mother and siblings after they were swept out to sea.
